metadata.case_name: Mamidi China Venkata Sivayya (deceased) & Ors. v. Narasimhaswamy & Ors.

facts.text: Small Cause Suit No. 9 of 1953 resulted in a decree against Narasimhaswamy and his four sons, members of a Mitakshara Hindu joint family.
In execution of the decree, shares of the four sons (described as 4/5th share) in joint family properties auctioned on December 21, 1936, and purchased by Sivayya, whose successors are appellants.
Narasimhaswamy's share not put up for sale as insolvency application pending.
Order dated November 6, 1939 under O. 21, rr. 35 and 96 CPC for delivery of joint possession to Prakasalingam along with joint family members; possession delivered symbolically by beat of drum.
Prakasalingam re-transferred properties to Sivayya on April 11, 1945.
Fifth son, Venugopal, born to Narasimhaswamy before auction sale; not made party to suit or execution; share reduced to 2/3rd for four sons.
Sivayya filed suit on October 16, 1951 against joint family members and alienees for partition into five equal shares and possession of four shares.
Trial Court decreed suit for 2/3rd share, not 4/5th.
High Court (Andhra Pradesh) allowed defendants' appeal on limitation under Art. 144 Limitation Act; dismissed cross-objection without merits.
Sivayya died pending High Court appeal; appellants as successors appealed to Supreme Court under Art. 133 Constitution.
Narasimhaswamy's insolvency annulled subsequently; no claim against his share.

legal_issues.text: Whether the suit was barred by limitation under Art. 144 or Art. 120 of the Limitation Act.
Whether Sivayya was entitled to 4/5th share or only 2/3rd share in partition due to birth of fifth son.

petitioner_arguments.text: Suit not barred by limitation; symbolic delivery of possession on November 6, 1939 interrupted adverse possession of defendants.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 144 Limitation Act; O. 21 rr. 35, 96 CPC; Sri Radha Krishna Chanderji v. Ram Bahadur

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if Art. 144 applies, time runs from 1939 delivery, suit within 12 years.
Entitled to 4/5th share as purchased at auction.
Art. 120: No accrual of right to sue as no threat to infringe right.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 120 Limitation Act; Mst. Rukhmabai v. Lala Laxminarayan; C. Mohammad Yunus v. Syed Unnissa

respondent_arguments.text: Suit barred under Art. 144 from date of auction sale (Dec 21, 1936); symbolic delivery nullity as purchaser of undivided share not entitled to possession.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 144 Limitation Act; Mahant Sudarsan Das v. Mahan Ram Kirpal Das; Yelumalai Chetti v. Srinivasa Chetti

respondent_arguments.text: Art. 120 applies, limitation from date of sale.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 120 Limitation Act; Bai Shevantibai v. Janardan R. Warick

respondent_arguments.text: Symbolic delivery had no legal effect; did not interrupt adverse possession.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Mahadev Sakharam Parkar v. Janu Namji Hatle; Jang Bahadur Singh v. Hanwant Singh

court_reasoning.text: Art. 144 problematic for suit by purchaser of undivided share as no right to possession until partition; but assuming applies, symbolic delivery on Nov 6, 1939 interrupted adverse possession as factual interruption, even if order erroneous but not nullity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Delivery of possession under O.21 rr.35,96 CPC, though legally wrong, had effect unless set aside; time runs from 1939.

court_reasoning.text: Under Art. 120, right to sue accrues only on threat to infringe right; no such threat here.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Bai Shevantibai incorrectly stated limitation from sale date.

court_reasoning.text: Purchased shares of four sons only; fifth son born before sale, not party, so only 2/3rd share.
court_reasoning.key_observation: What sold was shares of four brothers at date of sale.

court_reasoning.text: Ramaswami J. concurs: Suit for possession via partition falls under Art. 144; adverse possession from purchase date but interrupted by 1939 symbolic delivery, which was effective despite illegality.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Symbolic possession breaks continuity of adverse possession.

holdings.text: Suit not barred by limitation under Art. 144 or 120.
Sivayya entitled only to 2/3rd share, not 4/5th or 5/6th.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sidheshwar Mukherjee v. Bhubneshwar Prasad Narain
precedents_cited.relevance: Purchaser of coparcener's undivided interest not entitled to possession until partition.
Adverse possession not against person not entitled to possession.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mahant Sudarsan Das v. Mahan Ram Kirpal Das
precedents_cited.relevance: Art. 144 applies to interest in property; adverse possession of undivided share possible.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sri Radha Krishna Chanderji v. Ram Bahadur

precedents_cited.relevance: Order for possession not nullity; court had jurisdiction though erred.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mahadev Sakharam Parkar v. Janu Namji Hatle
precedents_cited.relevance: Symbolic delivery interrupts only if in accordance with law; here it was.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jang Bahadur Singh v. Hanwant Singh
Bai Shevantibai v. Janardan R. Warick
precedents_cited.relevance: Art. 120 limitation from sale date incorrect.
Art. 120: right to sue on accrual and threat.

precedents_cited.case_name: C. Mohammad Yunus v. Syed Unnissa

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Governing period for suit for possession/partition by alienee; 12 years from adverse possession or 6 years from right accrual.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Symbolic delivery of joint possession interrupts adverse possession.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment set aside except dismissal of cross-objection; trial court decree restored granting partition and possession of 2/3rd share.
outcome.relief_granted: Partition and separate possession of 2/3rd share to appellants.
outcome.costs: Appellants entitled to proportionate costs in Supreme Court and High Court.

key_quotes.text: the purchaser of a coparcener's undivided interest in joint family property is not entitled to possession of what he has purchased. His only right is to sue for partition.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: By the delivery of symbolical possession under the order of November 6, 1939, the adverse possession of the defendants was interrupted.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key to rejecting limitation bar under Art. 144.

key_quotes.text: the right to sue accrues for the purpose of Art. 120 when there is an accrual of the right asserted in the suit and an unequivocal threat by the respondent to infringe it.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: What was purchased at the execution sale was only the shares of Venugopal's four brothers at the date of the sale and this was 2/3rd.
key_quotes.speaker: court
